text.headline: Born
text.text: Born in Halle, Germany to Georg Händel and Dorothea Taust

text.headline: Age 17: studies law
text.text: Handel studies law at Halle University and is appointed organist of the Calvinist Cathedral

text.headline: Age 18: moves to Hamburg
text.text: Handel moves to Hamburg, plays violin and harpsichord in the opera orchestra at Theater am Gänsemarkt, now Hamburg State Opera

text.headline: Age 20: first performance of Almira
text.text: Handel's first opera, Almira, is performed and is a success. It ran for twenty performances.

text.headline: Age 21: moves to Italy
text.text: Handel moves to Italy

text.headline: Age 22: writes Rodrigo
text.text: Handel writes his first Italian opera, Rodrigo

text.headline: Age 24: first performance of Agrippina
text.text: The first performance of Agrippina is very well received and its popularity makes a name for Handel in Italy

text.headline: Age 25: appointed Court Music Director
text.text: Handel is appointed Court Music Director ('Kapellmeister') to the Hanoverian court in June and is granted permission to travel to London, where he is presented to Queen Anne

text.headline: Age 26: presents Rinaldo
text.text: Handel presents Rinaldo, his first Italian opera written specially for the London audience

text.headline: Age 28: Writes Te Deum
text.text: Having returned to Hanover and then travelled back to London a second time, Handel writes the Te Deum and Ode for the Birthday of Queen Anne and is given an annual royal pension (salary) of £200

text.headline: Age 29: Handel settles in London
text.text: Queen Anne dies and Handel's Hanoverian employer, George Elector of Hanover, is crowned George I of Great Britain. Handel settles in London

text.headline: Age 32: First performance of Water Music
text.text: The first Performance of Handel's Water Music takes place on 17 July as part of a public procession of King George I and his dignitaries down the River Thames

text.headline: Age 34: Royal Academy of Music established
text.text: The Royal Academy of Music is established by nobility for performances of Italian opera under Handel’s direction

text.headline: Age 38: Moves to Brook Street
text.text: Appointed Composer of Musick for His Majesty's Chappel Royal and granted an additional annual royal pension. Handel moves to Brook Street, London where he lives for the rest of his life

text.headline: Age 39: First performance of Giulio Cesare
text.text: First performance of Giulio Cesare; The start of a succession of longer and more detailed operas that include Tamerlano (1724) and Rodelinda (1725)

text.headline: Age 42: Granted British Citizenship
text.text: George I dies and is succeeded by George II. Handel is granted British Citizenship and is appointed to write the Coronation Anthems, which include Zadok the Priest

text.headline: Age 43: Royal Academy of Music declares bankrupcy
text.text: The Royal Academy of Music declares bankruptcy leaving Handel to continue producing operas with his own funds

text.headline: Age 44: Partnership with James Heidegger
text.text: Handel establishes a partnership with John James Heidegger, the manager of the King's Theatre

text.headline: Age 46: Thomas Arne launches 'English Opera'
text.text: Thomas Arne launches a successful run of 'English Opera' in competition with Handel

text.headline: Age 47: Esther introduced
text.text: Handel introduces performances of an English oratorio, Esther to his season

text.headline: Age 49: Opera of the Nobility established
text.text: Opera of the Nobility is established as a successful rival to Handel's company stealing the majority of Handel's singers and moving into the King's Theatre in Handel's place where he performed his operas from 1711

text.headline: Age 50: First performance of Ariodante
text.text: The first performance of Ariodante takes place at the Covent Garden Theatre, owned by John Rich. Handel had full use of the in-house chorus and dance-company

text.headline: Age 53: Writes Saul and Israel in Egypt
text.text: Handel writes oratorios Saul and Israel in Egypt, which are premiered at the King’s Theatre the next year. A statue of Handel, by Roubilliac, is unveiled in Vauxhall Gardens

text.headline: Age 54: Produces first all-English season
text.text: Handel produces his first all-English season at a small theatre at Lincoln's Inn Fields, including L'Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato and the Ode for St Cecilia's Day

text.headline: Age 55: Last season of Italian Opera
text.text: Handel presents his last season of Italian opera in London

text.headline: Age 56: Composes Messiah
text.text: Handel is invited to Dublin by the Duke of Devonshire, William Cavendish for the winter concert season. He composes Messiah in 24 days from 22 August to 14 September

text.headline: Age 57: First performance of Messiah
text.text: The first performance of Messiah takes place in Dublin on 13 April. It is a resounding success

text.headline: Age 58: George II defeats the French army
text.text: George II defeats the French army at Dettingen. Handel writes Dettingen Te Deum and Anthem as a celebration. Handel writes Semele in 4 weeks

text.headline: Age 61: Handel writes Judas Maccabeus
text.text: Handel writes Judas Maccabeus to celebrate George II’s victory over the Jacobites at the Battle of Culloden

text.headline: Age 63: Handel writes Solomon
text.text: Handel writes Solomon, which includes the famous instrumental passage for two oboes and strings known as The Arrival of the Queen of Sheeba. Further oratorios such as Joshua and Alexander Balus are performed and are very well received.

text.headline: Age 64: Handel writes Music for the Royal Fireworks
text.text: Handel writes Music for the Royal Fireworks to celebrate the end of The War of the Austrian Succession. The first annual performance of Messiah as a benefit concert for the Foundling Hospital is held

text.headline: Age 66: Begins to lose sight
text.text: Handel begins to lose the sight in his left eye whilst composing Jephtha

text.headline: Age 67: Handel's sight almost gone
text.text: Despite managing to perform Jephtha at the beginning of the year, Handel's sight is almost completely gone by the end of the year

text.headline: Age 68: Handel starts performing again
text.text: After a brief period of convalescence, Handel starts performing again from memory and through improvisation

text.headline: Age 69: JC Smith the younger takes over annual benefit concerts
text.text: Handel hands over the responsibility of the annual benefit concerts for the Foundling Hospital to J C Smith the younger, Handel's amanuensis

text.headline: Age 73: Handel attends a revival of Messiah on 6 April
text.text: On 11 April Handel modifies his Will for the fourth time, bequeathing £1000 to the Society for the Support of Decayed Musicians and desiring burial in Westminster Abbey and for a monument of him to be erected there. He bequeaths £600 for the monument.

text.headline: Age 74: Handel dies
text.text: Handel dies at 25 Brook Street on 13 April and is buried at Westminster Abbey a week later on 20 April
